item.title: The Lede: Former President of Iran Disqualified From Race to Succeed Ahmadinejad, State TV Says
item.description: Iran’s state television announced Tuesday that Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a two-term former president who called for greater freedom during protests in 2009, has been barred from running in next month’s election to succeed President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A photograph released by the office of Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, right, showed him meeting with Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a former president, last year in Tehran.

item.title: Iran Bars Mashaei and Rafsanjani as Candidates
item.description: A vetting panel rejected Esfandiar Rahim Mashaei, an ally of President Ahmadinejad, and former President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Depardieu, Newly a Russian, Will Play a Chechen in Films
item.description: Gérard Depardieu, who renounced his French citizenship over high taxes, held a news conference in Grozny, the formerly war-torn Chechen capital, to announce the two films.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: At War Blog: Married to the Marines
item.description: A military spouse reflects on the pros and cons of being married to a marine as he retires from the Corps after 20 years of service.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MOLLY BLAKE
item.media:description: Molly and Peter Blake at the Marine Corps Air Station at Yuma, Ariz., in December 2010.

item.title: World Brief | Europe: 4 Held in Attack on Georgia Gay Rights Advocates
item.description: Prime minister Bidzina Ivanishvili has called for prosecutions following the violence, but the case is expected to upset his relations with the church.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: World Brief | Europe: Right-Wing Writer Kills Himself in Notre-Dame in Paris
item.description: The man, Dominique Venner, had published a blog post denouncing the passage of a same-sex marriage law.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: Bike Share in New York, Built From Ideas Around World
item.description: When Citi Bike is introduced in New York next week, it will resemble a sort of cycling stew — a system that borrows pieces of similar programs in other cities.
item.dc:creator: By MATT FLEGENHEIMER
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: Ed Alcock for The New York Times; Alex Wong/Getty Images; Facundo Arrizabalaga/European Pressphoto Agency;and Lourdes Segade for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Bloomberg administration studied bike share systems in several cities, including, clockwise from top left, Paris, Washington, London and Barcelona.

item.title: World Brief | Middle East : Israel Extends Zone for Fishing Off Gaza
item.description: As Secretary of State John Kerry flew to the Middle East, officials canceled a three-mile limit imposed in March after Gaza militants fired rockets into Israel.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and FARES AKRAM

item.title: Ally of Georgia’s Leader Charged With Abuse of Power
item.description: The head of President Mikheil Saakashvili’s party was held in connection with an employment program that prosecutors say was used to pay campaign workers.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: May 21
item.description: A snake show in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh, on the eve of International Day for Biological Diversity.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A snake show in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh, on the eve of International Day for Biological Diversity. In 2002, the United Nations designated May 22 as the day to spread awareness about issues of biodiversity.

item.title: Syrian and Hezbollah Fighters Push Qusayr Assault
item.description: Airstrikes were reported on Tuesday amid conflicting accounts about the progress of the battle for Qusayr, a town in western Syrian long held by anti-government forces.
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Unicorns Travel From Paris to Japan
item.description: The Cluny Museum’s tapestries of “The Lady and the Unicorn” travel to Tokyo and Osaka, and alabaster mourners from Dijon make a stopover in Paris.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:description: The Cluny Museum's tapestry "The Lady and the Unicorn."

item.title: Torture Victim’s Body Is Found Near U.S. Base, Afghans Say
item.description: Afghan investigators say the man was seen in a videotape undergoing torture at the hands of an Afghan-American translator for a United States Special Forces unit.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: The Female Factor: Leading a Push for Clean Water
item.description: The involvement of women has been crucial to ensuring more reliable sources of drinking water in rural India.
item.dc:creator: By NILANJANA S. ROY

item.title: Myanmar Muslims Jailed for Killing Buddhist Monk
item.description: A Myanmar court sentenced seven Muslims to prison Tuesday, one of them to a life term, in the killing of a Buddhist monk.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Budget-Conscious Scotland Yard Moving to Smaller Home
item.description: Scotland Yard is a name that evokes a fogbound Victorian era of mystery, murder and mayhem. In these tough economic times, the headquarters of London’s police force will soon be relocating as part of a money-saving strategy.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: A police officer outside Scotland Yard's planned new headquarters in central London on Monday.

item.title: Coalition Plays Down Afghan Reports of Major Battle in Helmand
item.description: Afghan officials portrayed the fighting as a big victory against the Taliban, but the American-led coalition was circumspect about the scale of the battle.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and TAIMOOR SHAH

item.title: In New Delhi, Chinese Leader Promotes Trade Ties
item.description: Speaking to business leaders in the Indian capital, Prime Minister Li Keqiang said a “few clouds in the sky” couldn’t disrupt the Asian giants’ relationship.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 21
item.description: Deadly tornado in Oklahoma; Hezbollah in Lebanon; politics in Germany and Italy; garden gnomes in Chelsea; Yahoo’s rush into social media; a Franco-American movie in Cannes.
item.dc:creator: By INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Lebanese mourners carried Hezbollah fighter Hassan Faisal Shuker, 18, through Nabi Sheet, Lebanon in the Bekaa Valley. Shuker was reportedly killed fighting against Syrian rebels in the Syrian town of Qusair.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Does U.S. Violence Scare Students Away?
item.description: Concern among international students and their parents about safety on American campuses long predates the Boston Marathon bombings.
item.dc:creator: By JOYCE LAU
item.media:description: A memorial service for Sean A. Collier, the M.I.T. campus police officer who the authorities say was gunned down by the suspects in the bombings.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Storm in a Dipping Bowl Over Europe’s Olive Oil Rule
item.description: Even the European Union’s supporters are suggesting that the alliance’s bureaucrats might have better things to do than tampering with the way olive oil is served in the Continent’s restaurants.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Olive oil on sale at Domaine de l'Oulivie in southern France.

item.title: Obama Couples Praise for Burmese Leader With Warning Against Violence
item.description: President Obama encouraged the political and economic reforms in Myanmar, but warned the country’s visiting leader, President Thein Sein, that violence against minority Muslims had to stop.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Author A. X. Ahmad
item.description: Mr. Ahmad on his upcoming mystery novel “The Caretaker,” and HarperCollins’s India initiative to publish a series of mysteries from Indian authors.
item.dc:creator: By SHIVANI VORA

item.title: Guatemala’s Highest Court Overturns Genocide Conviction of Former Dictator
item.description: The decision, which reset the proceedings to April 19, when a judge’s ruling sent the trial into disarray, is a dramatic legal victory for Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt, 86.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Earlier this month, the former dictator Efraín Ríos Montt was sentenced to 80 years in prison.

item.title: Immigrant Death Rate Rises on Illegal Crossings
item.description: Migrant deaths remain high even as apprehensions have fallen, with tighter borders pushing people to take riskier routes from Mexico to the United States.
item.dc:creator: By FERNANDA SANTOS and REBEKAH ZEMANSKY
item.media:credit: Joshua Lott for The New York Times
item.media:description: The skeletal remains of a migrant, found by hikers in April, are stored at the Pima County Medical Examiner’s Office in Tucson.
